    Using characterize with tidymodels

    Using characterize with tidymodels

    Using_characterize_with_tidymodels.Rmd

    This tutorial will demonstrate how characterize can be used to understand how your model works.

    First, let’s generate some data where there are 10 informative parameters and 50 that are non-informative. The sim_regression() function in the modeldata package can be used to simulate numerous equations. We’ll use the method of Hooker (2004), which uses the equation:

    \[ y_{i} = \pi^{x_{i1} x_{i2}} \sqrt{ 2 x_{i3} } - sin^{-1}(x_{i4}) + \log(x_{i5} + x_{i5}) - (x_{i9} / x_{i10}) \sqrt{x_{i7} / x_{i8}} - x_{i2} x_{i7} + \epsilon_{i} \]

    We’ll also create a set of cross-validation indices form the training set:

    library(tidymodels)
library(characterize)
tidymodels_prefer()
theme_set(theme_bw())


set.seed(4005)
sim_train <- 
  sim_regression(1000, method = "hooker_2004") %>% 
  bind_cols(sim_noise(1000, 50))

sim_train
    ## # A tibble: 1,000 × 61
##    outcome predictor_01 predictor_02 predictor_03 predictor_04 predictor_05
##      <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>        <dbl>
##  1 -1.10         0.413        0.328        0.0226        0.633        0.837
##  2 -0.501        0.850        0.261        0.129         0.956        0.693
##  3 -0.564        0.701        0.482        0.0332        0.834        0.727
##  4 -0.560        0.129        0.226        0.685         0.833        0.755
##  5  1.10         0.0378       0.205        1.00          0.698        0.989
##  6  0.320        0.722        0.137        0.942         0.748        0.655
##  7  0.836        0.0379       0.0820       0.831         0.679        0.865
##  8  2.52         0.762        0.991        0.937         0.690        0.634
##  9  0.0555       0.825        0.195        0.443         0.942        0.694
## 10 -1.35         0.671        0.333        0.226         0.949        0.915
## # ℹ 990 more rows
## # ℹ 55 more variables: predictor_06 <dbl>, predictor_07 <dbl>,
## #   predictor_08 <dbl>, predictor_09 <dbl>, predictor_10 <dbl>, noise_01 <dbl>,
## #   noise_02 <dbl>, noise_03 <dbl>, noise_04 <dbl>, noise_05 <dbl>,
## #   noise_06 <dbl>, noise_07 <dbl>, noise_08 <dbl>, noise_09 <dbl>,
## #   noise_10 <dbl>, noise_11 <dbl>, noise_12 <dbl>, noise_13 <dbl>,
## #   noise_14 <dbl>, noise_15 <dbl>, noise_16 <dbl>, noise_17 <dbl>, …
    sim_rs <- vfold_cv(sim_train)

    A single model fit

    Let’s fit a regression tree to these data:

    cart_fit <- 
  decision_tree(cost_complexity = 0.05) %>% 
  set_mode("regression") %>% 
  fit(outcome ~ ., data = sim_train)
cart_fit
    ## parsnip model object
## 
## n= 1000 
## 
## node), split, n, deviance, yval
##       * denotes terminal node
## 
##  1) root 1000 675.56010  0.132640600  
##    2) predictor_03< 0.4294012 401 169.56340 -0.398818000  
##      4) predictor_07>=0.3936169 247  88.29824 -0.650205000 *
##      5) predictor_07< 0.3936169 154  40.62021  0.004380685 *
##    3) predictor_03>=0.4294012 599 316.91210  0.488425100  
##      6) predictor_01< 0.5095151 306  92.81308  0.204690200 *
##      7) predictor_01>=0.5095151 293 173.73660  0.784749000  
##       14) predictor_02< 0.674366 182  55.90145  0.472063700 *
##       15) predictor_02>=0.674366 111  70.86405  1.297440000 *

    Fit this particular model, there are a few aspects of this model that can be quantified using characterize():

    characterize(cart_fit)
    ## # A tibble: 2 × 3
##   .metric             .estimator .estimate
##   <chr>               <chr>          <dbl>
## 1 num_active_features model              4
## 2 num_term_nodes      model              5

    These values can help understand the complexity of the model. Each aspect is determined by individual functions that start with .pluck, such as .pluck_num_active_features(). Almost all of these functions return numeric values. The one exception can return which predictors are functionally used in the prediction equation:

    .pluck_active_features(cart_fit)
    ## # A tibble: 1 × 2
##   statistic       value    
##   <chr>           <list>   
## 1 active_features <chr [4]>
    # to get them: 
.pluck_active_features(cart_fit) %>% 
  unnest(value)
    ## # A tibble: 4 × 2
##   statistic       value       
##   <chr>           <chr>       
## 1 active_features predictor_01
## 2 active_features predictor_02
## 3 active_features predictor_03
## 4 active_features predictor_07

    Different models will return different types of model characteristics and some will not return any:

    ppr(outcome ~ ., data = sim_train, nterms = 3) %>% 
  characterize()
    ## # A tibble: 0 × 3
## # ℹ 3 variables: .metric <chr>, .estimator <chr>, .estimate <dbl>

    Characterizing the models from tuning

    We night want to know how these characteristics related to model performance. Let’s tune this model. The cost-complexity parameter (aka Cp) is modulated over 20 different values. These models are fit on each of the 10 resamples of the data.

    The tuning functions in tidymodels have an option to return the fitted models (or some results that are based on those models). The extract option in the control functions can be used to define what will be returned. We’ll use the retain_characteristics() function. This will execute characterize() on each of the models.

    cart_spec <- 
  decision_tree(cost_complexity = tune()) %>% 
  set_mode("regression")

ctrl <- control_grid(extract = retain_characteristics)

cart_res <-
  cart_spec %>%
  tune_grid(
    outcome ~ .,
    resamples = sim_rs,
    grid = tibble(cost_complexity = 10 ^ seq(-4, -1, length.out = 20)),
    control = ctrl
  )
cart_res
    ## # Tuning results
## # 10-fold cross-validation 
## # A tibble: 10 × 5
##    splits            id     .metrics          .notes           .extracts        
##    <list>            <chr>  <list>            <list>           <list>           
##  1 <split [900/100]> Fold01 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
##  2 <split [900/100]> Fold02 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
##  3 <split [900/100]> Fold03 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
##  4 <split [900/100]> Fold04 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
##  5 <split [900/100]> Fold05 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
##  6 <split [900/100]> Fold06 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
##  7 <split [900/100]> Fold07 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
##  8 <split [900/100]> Fold08 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
##  9 <split [900/100]> Fold09 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>
## 10 <split [900/100]> Fold10 <tibble [40 × 5]> <tibble [0 × 3]> <tibble [20 × 3]>

    Note that this is now a column called .extracts. Each resample has a corresponding tibble with 20 rows:

    cart_res$.extracts[[1]] %>% head()
    ## # A tibble: 6 × 3
##   cost_complexity .extracts        .config              
##             <dbl> <list>           <chr>                
## 1        0.0001   <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model01
## 2        0.000144 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model02
## 3        0.000207 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model03
## 4        0.000298 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model04
## 5        0.000428 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model05
## 6        0.000616 <tibble [1 × 1]> Preprocessor1_Model06
    # Getting closer:
cart_res$.extracts[[1]]$.extracts[[1]]
    ## # A tibble: 1 × 1
##   results         
##   <list>          
## 1 <tibble [2 × 3]>
    # The actual results: 
cart_res$.extracts[[1]]$.extracts[[1]]$results
    ## [[1]]
## # A tibble: 2 × 3
##   .metric             .estimator .estimate
##   <chr>               <chr>          <dbl>
## 1 num_active_features model             26
## 2 num_term_nodes      model             76

    Before you open the help files for tidyr::unnest(), or stop reading, there is a helper function that will put the results in a usable format:

    model_char <- collect_characteristics(cart_res)
model_char
    ## # A tibble: 40 × 7
##    cost_complexity .metric             .estimator  mean     n std_err .config   
##              <dbl> <chr>               <chr>      <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>     
##  1        0.0001   num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces…
##  2        0.0001   num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces…
##  3        0.000144 num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces…
##  4        0.000144 num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces…
##  5        0.000207 num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces…
##  6        0.000207 num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces…
##  7        0.000298 num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces…
##  8        0.000298 num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces…
##  9        0.000428 num_active_features model       26.7    10    1.16 Preproces…
## 10        0.000428 num_term_nodes      model       73.4    10    1.03 Preproces…
## # ℹ 30 more rows

    The values in the mean column are the average characteristics. There is an option called summarize that can indicate that the individual model results should be returned.

    What is the relationship between the tuning parameter and the characteristics?

    model_char %>% 
  ggplot(aes(cost_complexity, mean)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line(alpha = 1 / 2) + 
  facet_wrap(~ .metric, scales = "free_y") + 
  scale_x_log10() +
  labs(y = NULL)

    That great but you probably want to know how these characteristics relate to model performance. Another option, add_metrics = TRUE will also collect the performance metrics (RMSE and R2) are row-bound to the previous results.

    metric_and_char <- collect_characteristics(cart_res, add_metrics = TRUE)
metric_and_char
    ## # A tibble: 80 × 7
##    cost_complexity .metric             .estimator   mean     n std_err .config  
##              <dbl> <chr>               <chr>       <dbl> <int>   <dbl> <chr>    
##  1        0.0001   num_active_features model      26.7      10 1.16    Preproce…
##  2        0.0001   num_term_nodes      model      73.4      10 1.03    Preproce…
##  3        0.0001   rmse                standard    0.542    10 0.00753 Preproce…
##  4        0.0001   rsq                 standard    0.587    10 0.0191  Preproce…
##  5        0.000144 num_active_features model      26.7      10 1.16    Preproce…
##  6        0.000144 num_term_nodes      model      73.4      10 1.03    Preproce…
##  7        0.000144 rmse                standard    0.542    10 0.00753 Preproce…
##  8        0.000144 rsq                 standard    0.587    10 0.0191  Preproce…
##  9        0.000207 num_active_features model      26.7      10 1.16    Preproce…
## 10        0.000207 num_term_nodes      model      73.4      10 1.03    Preproce…
## # ℹ 70 more rows
    metric_and_char %>% 
  ggplot(aes(cost_complexity, mean)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line(alpha = 1 / 2) + 
  facet_wrap(~ .metric, scales = "free_y") + 
  scale_x_log10()+
  labs(y = NULL)

    Another way to do this is to pivot the performance metrics to columns. From here, we can plot versus performance:

    rmse_vs_vars <- collect_characteristics(cart_res, add_metrics = TRUE, wide = TRUE)
rmse_vs_vars %>% head()
    ## # A tibble: 6 × 6
##   cost_complexity num_active_features num_term_nodes  rmse   rsq .config        
##             <dbl>               <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>          
## 1        0.0001                  26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_…
## 2        0.000144                26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_…
## 3        0.000207                26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_…
## 4        0.000298                26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_…
## 5        0.000428                26.7           73.4 0.542 0.587 Preprocessor1_…
## 6        0.000616                26.5           72.6 0.541 0.588 Preprocessor1_…
    rmse_vs_vars %>%
  ggplot(aes(num_active_features, rmse)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line(alpha = 1 / 2) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.55, lty = 2, col = "green")

    Recall that there are only 10 informative predictors. Selecting those out results in sudden and severe under-fitting. Keeping too many in the model results in a slow degradation of performance.

    One thing that we might also desire to know is “what’s the minimum number of features that will give me an RMSE less than 0.55?”

    rmse_vs_vars %>% 
  filter(rmse <= 0.55) %>% 
  slice_min(num_active_features, n = 1)
    ## # A tibble: 1 × 6
##   cost_complexity num_active_features num_term_nodes  rmse   rsq .config        
##             <dbl>               <dbl>          <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>          
## 1         0.00546                 7.4           24.9 0.540 0.571 Preprocessor1_…
